guarantee.title: About Guarantee Companies
guarantee.conclusion: Conclusion: With a guarantee company, you can sign a contract without a Japanese guarantor

whatIs.title: What is a Guarantee Company?
whatIs.desc: A guarantee company pays the landlord on behalf of the tenant if they cannot pay rent. About 80% of rental properties in Japan require or recommend using a guarantee company.

benefits.title: Benefits of Using a Guarantee Company
list: Easier for foreigners to sign contracts
Some companies only require an emergency contact

income.name: Income Stability
income.desc: Monthly income should be 3x rent. Full-time employees have advantage, but part-timers with long tenure can pass

visa.name: Visa Status & Duration
visa.desc: Visa duration should ideally exceed contract period. Work visa, student visa, permanent residence, etc.

history.name: Payment History
history.desc: Past rent or credit card payment delays may affect screening

contact.name: Emergency Contact
contact.desc: Having an emergency contact in Japan improves your chances

documents.title: Documents for Guarantee Company Application
required: Income certificate (tax withholding slip, 3 months payslips, or tax return)
Employment information (company name, address, phone, years employed)
optional: Bank balance certificate (if income proof is difficult)

tips.title: Tips to Pass Screening
list: Choose a property with rent below 1/3 of your income
Secure an emergency contact (friend, colleague, language school, etc.)
Choose a guarantee company experienced with foreigners

foreignerFriendly.title: Foreigner-Friendly Guarantee Companies
foreignerFriendly.desc: These companies are experienced with foreign applicants

cautions: Even if rejected by one company, another might approve you
You can apply to multiple guarantee companies
Ask your real estate agent to recommend foreigner-friendly companies

documents.title: Required Documents for Rental
documents.conclusion: Conclusion: Prepare documents in advance for a smooth contract process

residenceCard.name: Residence Card
residenceCard.desc: Both sides copy required. Check expiration date.
residenceCard.where: Issued at entry or Immigration Bureau

passport.name: Passport
passport.desc: Photo page copy. Visa page may also be required.

certificate.name: Resident Certificate (Juminhyo)
certificate.desc: Issued within 3 months. May need all household members.
certificate.where: City/Ward office or convenience store with My Number Card

employment.name: Employment Certificate
employment.desc: Issued by employer. States company, position, tenure, salary.

taxCertificate.name: Tax Withholding Certificate
taxCertificate.desc: Proves previous year income. Issued at year end.

bankStatement.name: Bank Balance Certificate
bankStatement.desc: Alternative if income proof is difficult. 1-2 years rent in savings helps.

sponsor.name: Remittance/Scholarship Certificate
sponsor.desc: Proof of family support or scholarship.
sponsor.where: Bank transfer history or scholarship organization

seal.name: Personal Seal (Inkan)
seal.desc: Used to stamp contracts. Regular seal usually OK.

tips: Documents should be in Japanese. Foreign documents may need translation
Check residence card is not expired
Most documents must be issued within 3 months
Confirm requirements with real estate agent in advance

1R.name: 1R (One Room)
1R.desc: A single room with kitchen area combined

1K.name: 1K
1K.desc: One room with a separate kitchen

1DK.name: 1DK
1DK.desc: One room with a dining kitchen

1LDK.name: 1LDK
1LDK.desc: One room with a living dining kitchen

tatami.name: Tatami
tatami.desc: Traditional Japanese floor mat. 1 tatami ≈ 1.65 m²

UB.name: UB (Unit Bath)
UB.desc: Combined bathroom with bath, toilet, and sink

rules.title: House Rules
rules.conclusion: Conclusion: Consideration for neighbors is important in Japanese rental housing

noise.name: Noise Awareness
noise.desc: Be especially quiet at night (after 9 PM). Be mindful of music and conversation volume.

garbage.name: Garbage Disposal
garbage.desc: Dispose of garbage on designated days, times, and locations. Separation is required.

shoes.name: Remove Shoes
shoes.desc: Remove shoes indoors. Take off shoes at the entrance.

pets.name: Pets
pets.desc: Pets are prohibited unless the property allows them. Check your contract.

smoking.name: Smoking
smoking.desc: Many properties prohibit indoor smoking. Balcony smoking may also be restricted.

guests.name: Guests
guests.desc: Long-term guests may need to be reported to the landlord.

renovation.name: Renovation/DIY
renovation.desc: Modifications like drilling holes are often prohibited.

cautions: Rule violations may result in eviction
Ask the landlord or management company if unsure

guarantor.q: What if I don't have a guarantor?
guarantor.a: You can use a guarantee company. Many properties accept guarantee companies. If you pass their screening, you can sign a contract without a personal guarantor.

japanese.q: Can I rent without speaking Japanese?
japanese.a: Yes, by using a real estate agency that offers foreign language support or an interpreter service. Contracts are in Japanese, but some agencies provide translations.

documents.a: Common documents: Residence card, passport, income proof (employment certificate, pay slips), resident certificate. Additional documents may be required depending on the property.

refused.q: Can I be refused because I'm a foreigner?
refused.a: Unfortunately, some landlords refuse foreign tenants. We recommend looking for foreigner-friendly properties or using agencies experienced with foreign clients.

shortTerm.q: Can I rent for a short period?
shortTerm.a: Standard rental contracts are usually 2 years. For short-term stays, consider monthly or weekly apartments.

internet.a: Some properties include free internet. Otherwise, you need to contract with a provider yourself. Mobile Wi-Fi is also an option.

deposit.name: Deposit

rules.title: Important Notes for Foreign Buyers
rules.conclusion: Conclusion: Foreigners can purchase Japanese real estate, but there are some considerations

eligibility.name: Eligibility
eligibility.desc: Foreigners can purchase Japanese real estate. Residence status is not required, but permanent residency is often required for mortgages.

loan.name: Mortgage
loan.desc: Without permanent residency, mortgage approval is strict. You may need to pay cash or find banks offering foreigner-specific loans.

tax.name: Taxes
tax.desc: Owning Japanese real estate requires annual property and city planning taxes. Tax returns may be necessary.

management.name: Property Management
management.desc: If you don't live in Japan, you need to hire a property management company.

reporting.name: Reporting Obligation
reporting.desc: Foreign buyers may need to report to the Ministry of Finance.

cautions: Consult professionals (agency, tax accountant, judicial scrivener)
Contracts are in Japanese. Consider translation services

foreigner.q: Can foreigners buy property in Japan?
foreigner.a: Yes, foreigners can purchase Japanese real estate without restrictions. Residence status is not required. However, there are conditions for mortgage loans.

loan.a: With permanent residency, most banks will lend. Without it, you may qualify if your spouse is Japanese, you have long employment history, or have a large down payment.

documents.a: Passport, residence card (if living in Japan), seal certificate, resident certificate, income proof. Overseas residents may need notarized documents.

remittance.q: Can I buy with overseas remittance?
remittance.a: Yes. However, proof of fund source is required for anti-money laundering. Start the process early as transfers take time.

rental.q: Can I rent out my purchased property?
rental.a: Yes. However, tax returns are required. We recommend using a property management company for tenant relations.

sell.a: Yes, you can sell anytime. Capital gains tax applies on profits. Tax rates differ based on ownership period.
